The 'Pamphiliidae' (sometimes incorrectly spelled 'Pamphilidae') are a small
family within the Symphyta, containing some 200 species from the temperate
regions of North America and Eurasia. The larvae feed on plants (often
conifers), using silk to either build webs or tents, or to roll leaves into
tubes, in which they feed, thus earning them the common names 'leaf-rolling
sawflies' or 'web-spinning sawflies'. They are distinguished from the closely
related Megalodontesidae by their simple, filiform antennae.
